tweets.content: @shreyas insofar as exposure to a true and free man gives another the permission to be honest and free within oneself, it can be "taught," but not in the way teaching is conventionally thought of. proximity to mastery can have an effect on a man's integrity.
@tsawrub everything gets misinterpreted by mostly everyone, the only honest excuse for such tirades is self-expression.

@tsawrub and i'm saying is arguments and counter arguments are all misplaced (why they don't work), because freedom is a purely individual pursuit and has its origins in the nature of one's relationship to the world.

@tsawrub if the individual focuses all his attention to himself, relativism will never enter the picture at all, for this individual will soon realise that people are largely best left alone. he won't be interested in persuading or prescribing.

the critique does have to be rooted in the real problem. it needs to point out root causes, not symptoms. and relativism is meaningless from my vantage, it only opens up a can of worms if it turns ideological and starts prescribing itself to others in a convenience-pilled manner. it's a collective notion that seeks consensus while promoting freedom.

things are never by default 'anything.' they're neither good, right, advisable, permitted, or any other qualifier. things derive their qualities from your relationship with them. if your relationship is that of need, attachment, and fear, nothing will let you be free. a thing might free you up in one way while imprisoning you in another.

ideological pessimism against tech, i.e., ludditism gloats over something unearned; over a long enough period, everything in the world goes to shit. that's just the nature of things. so there's nothing special or intelligent about pointing out degeneracy or experiencing schadenfreude over the world going to shit. culture is degenerating and regenerating all the time.

yes, there is a fundamental dishonesty underneath all of this freedom narrative. society and culture itself are prisons, how can any technology facilitating the same institutions ever bless you with freedom?

but the essence of the problem is never addressed in its full phenomenology; most anti-tech critique is constantly beating a strawman with a baseball bat and scoring ingroup points.

freedom is realizing, first and foremost, that freedom doesn't lie in things. it's a mode of being. things are merely utilitarian. functional.

honest problem identification is its own solution. what is the problem? a fact is not a problem. an obstacle to a motive is the problem. what's your motive and what's the obstacle? how and why is it an obstacle? is it really the actual obstacle or is the obstacle something else? are you honest about your motive?

i cannot emphasise how important asking yourself "what's the problem?" is. if you look into it honestly, you will realise you don't even know what's the specific problem *you* are experiencing. most of your problems are not your own. and because they aren't your own, you don't even understand them. so they never get solved, because there's nothing real to solve there. meanwhile, what's creating the actual discomfort and anxiety is not even being addressed.

the feed is closer to the full possibility space, the full nervous system, the totality of the mind laid out at once, yes, but at any given moment, you're living in one unique constitution, unique arrangement of conditions, along a single path-dependent timeline. saying "everyone is everything everywhere all at once" collapses this distinction. it treats the possibility-space as if it's already realized, but it isn't. failing to see this creates chronic contradiction and an insatiable yearning

the feed is non-ergodic. few people really grok this because it's so unintuitive.

in an ergodic system, the time average equals the ensemble average, meaning if you follow one person for 10 years, you'd see roughly the same distribution of events as watching 10,000 people for one day.

but the feed is radically non-ergodic because people only post the most interesting highlights, so the ensemble feed is sampling from a completely different distribution than any single person's actual time-series of life. you experience the ensemble synchronously. you see 100 people's best moments TODAY, which makes you think "this is what a normal day looks like" rather than "these are 100 people's best days from the past week, all shown to me at once." it makes rare things feels common. you think everyone's life is like this, when really you're just seeing the collective interestingness on any given day rather than the interestingness experienced by a single person.

if the feed were ergodic, scrolling for an hour would give you the same experience as following one person for 1,000 hours. but it doesn't. following one person for 1,000 hours would mostly bore you the fuck out. the feed hides all that.

our brains haven't evolved to compensate for this. you subconsciously extract time-average information (what is normal life like?) from ensemble-average data (what are the peaks of a million lives?), and it completely breaks your calibration.

big feed is a big contributor to the movie-brain.

i think ten is a good number to round this off. everything else about incentives, negotiations, negging, power dynamics, signalling, etc. you can learn from the books and your own observation.

the tenth crucial bit about sales and influence which you will learn the hard way, when you see others playing on easy mode:

don‚Äôt try to sell competence to the status-hungry, and status to the competence-hungry.
beautiful

the ninth crucial bit about sales and influence which only salespersons with integrity will tell you:

you don't stop selling and disappear once the deal is closed.

the eight crucial bit about sales and influence which everyone good at sales will tell you, but you won't internalise it if you don't care enough:

always be selling.

once you're selling, every interaction is sales, and no engagement with the prospect is not-sales.

the seventh crucial bit about sales and influence which only veterans will tell you is:

avoid having to sell as much as possible. let your product and people pull the weight.

so, a natural corollary to the sixth bit is:

being good at sales also necessarily includes the ability to find people you'd like selling to and selling for.

"but wait, isn't that what being good at sales is all about?"

yes it is, but it's also a great way to hate yourself, your job, and your life in the long run.

the sixth crucial bit about sales and influence no one will tell you (and this going to be highly debatable):

as much as possible, avoid *selling to* people you don't like, and *selling for* people you don't like.

the fifth crucial bit about sales and influence only a few will tell you: you can't sell without deeply understanding the prevailing culture, and this culture changes constantly. not being deeply interested in contemporary society and culture immediately hampers your ability to sell.

the fourth crucial bit about sales and influence no one will tell you: sales does not exist as a skillset independently in and of itself, although there are many playbooks and techniques documented on the art of selling. to be effective, you will need to have all of the above aligned.

the third crucial bit about sales and influence many will tell you today but it's not prescribable: without the ability to say fuck off and walk away from the table, you'll never be effective at sales or negotiation. people can smell your neediness from a mile away.

the second crucial bit about sales and influence no one will tell you: if you're genuinely not interested in what you're selling, you'll never be effective at selling. read all the sales and negotiation playbooks you want.
the crucial bit about sales and influence no one will tell you: if everyone is selling and influencing the same way by studying the same sales playbooks, no one is being effective at selling.

capitalism feels bad because technology's scaling effects turn minor advantages into runaway feedback loops. someone with marginally better starting conditions like talent, money, connections can now leverage those into exponentially growing gaps. what used to be linear differences become nonlinear divergences.

but at the same time, technology also provides you with countless micro-niches to hack your own status games on orthogonal dimensions. so it's not that bad. the internet has genuinely flattened access to eyeballs, know-how, and toolkits in ways that weren't possible before. someone can bootstrap a tribe, acquire competencies, or mint value in micro-markets that didn't exist a generation ago. but this doesn't equally benefit everyone; having the slack, steadiness, and taste-capital to navigate these new affordances is itself a privilege.

and it's easy to see this difference in privilege from the pov of the disadvantaged than it is to see from the pov of the advantaged.¬†

most affluent people never really appreciate how good they have it.¬†they tend to credit their success more to their own efforts and less to the conditions that made those efforts possible. and it's not malicious.¬†it's not like they're trying to be assholes, like the woke "billionaires should not exist" crowd would have you believe. but when you've always had decent wifi, a quiet room to think in, or folks who knew which fork to use and kept their shit together, in a house that wasn't scraping by and fighting over every petty penny, it's tough to really get what it's like living without that cushion.¬†it's hard to viscerally understand what it's like without those things.

what's far less obvious though, especially to people from affluent backgrounds, is that the technology that creates new opportunities often requires a specific type of cultural fluency that's almost invisible to those who have it. having internet access is one thing, but having the cultural aptitude and fluency is quite another. today,¬†someone from a working-class background technically has the same access to youtube or tiktok, but they're less likely to understand the nuances of personal branding, the importance of consistency, or how to optimize for discoverability. they don't have taste or know which aesthetic choices signal credibility to certain audiences.

this same cultural gap can sometimes also work in reverse, where people from disadvantaged backgrounds can bring fresh takes that resonate powerfully online. but it's rare. and even then, they often lack the meta-knowledge about how to systematically leverage these advantages because they've never understood capitalism or how fame or money works.

meanwhile, the privileged think they succeeded because they "worked harder" at content creation, when really they succeeded because they fluently spoke the cultural language that platforms reward, had the financial cushion to experiment without immediate returns, and possessed the social capital to get initial amplification.

and as these platforms mature and become more systematized, they increasingly tend to favor people who can treat content creation like a business, further advantaging those who are already raised to think like entrepreneurs and not like employees.

now, none of this is meant to excuse anyone's failures or deny anyone's successes. plenty of people from disadvantaged backgrounds do break through, and plenty of privileged people genuinely hustle and create value. the point isn't that circumstances determine everything or that individual agency doesn't matter ‚Äî it's that the playing field tilts in ways that compound over time, making certain outcomes more probable for certain people. technology does enable unprecedented upward mobility, but it also amplifies existing advantages in ways that make the overall distribution more skewed, not less.

the matthew principle lies at the core of capitalism x technology.

"to those who have, more will be given."

both capitalism and technology are presented as meritocratic systems. you're told that markets reward the best products and that algorithms surface the most relevant content. but in reality, both systems have strong preferential attachment dynamics, and success begets more success. each advantage compounds exponentially, not linearly.

this generates what appears as darwinian selection but is actually path-locked contingency. we spot the winners who made it through and assume they must have been the most adapted,¬†when often they just had better starting positions or caught the right breaks. sure, spotting and exploiting opportunities is core to capitalism;¬†that the capacity to spot and "leverage" any particular opening is¬†literally what the word means.¬†but now, you should obviously consider the whole stack of variables that make someone structurally primed to leverage.¬†step back and you'll notice how initial conditions ‚Äî family, geography, timing ‚Äî shape who gets to spot what. the game rewards those already positioned to play it.

so, both narratives ‚Äî "the system amplifies unfairness" and "there are more opportunities than ever" ‚Äî are simultaneously true. but the former is obviously more useful and actionable than the latter. because this inequality is simply the water we swim in; getting bitter about someone's better hand won't change your own cards, and resenting privilege mostly just corrodes your ability to play whatever game you can access. the unfairness is real, but hating the lucky for their luck is like hating gravity for making things fall; it's a waste of emotional energy that could be spent finding your own weird little arbitrage opportunities in the margins.

genuinely putting freedom at the core of your national ethos (unlike india, where the freedom the constitution espouses is just words on paper) creates a natural antifragile diversity and error-correction that's hard to be bearish on. good times and bad times are cyclical, but whether you can survive them and come out on relatively unhurt on the other side depends on how genuinely free people are to live life the way they wish to. it is fundamentally sound long-term error correction at the species level, regardless of the polarization you see today, which is also partly a social media phenomenon. 

now, india too shares some of this antifragility, but not because of the freedom the legal system empowers its citizens with, but because of the cultural chauvinism that never lets the country as a whole get together on the same page around any issue. it's both a blessing and a curse.

the usa is also a gifted country in many other regards, like natural diversity and abundance of resources.

things llms are good at

- synthesizing large amounts of text and code quickly
- understanding intent and reading between the lines
- fetching relevant information/knowledge from its own data (largest and most accessible library on earth)
- generating large amounts of text and code quickly, i.e., rapid prototyping
- emulating different styles and formats of writing
- teaching, explaining, conversing
- language translation

things llms are not good at

- non-trivial/novel pattern recognition and conjecturing
- knowing and working with hyperlocal cultural context
- thinking longterm
- disagreeability and knowing when to break its own rules
- metacognition, and knowing what it doesn't know
- editing
- maintaining logical consistency

many of these aren't mutually exclusive and feed into each other.

nothing about this app is complex, it's just a bunch of ways to extract a detailed prompt from the user and a couple of ingenious ways to leverage ai without producing slop. but the way i've implemented certain features is quite novel from any other ai-based text editor you'll find. at the same time, some really obvious massmarket friendly features are completely missing.

i'm so impressed by just how simple and useful this feature has turned out to be

it's like handing in a draft to your editor self, who goes through the piece and leaves comments and notes in places where more detail or clarity can be supplied by way of examples, descriptions, explanations, numbers, anything at all.

for instance, you could have two paragraphs that do not logically flow from each other, and you can simply add the logical connection between them as a prompt and let the ai fill it in

or you could have a really good cross-domain analogy in mind without the requisite chops to do justice to the articulation. just describe it as a prompt, choose an author who'd be best fit to make such a connection along with some stylistic settings and you get a really nice result.

being able to add prompts like this inline and letting the ai do the needful is just the way ai-augmented writing needs to work.

reality is what it is, but to a mind that loves clean and predictable narratives and abhors chaos, it can feel pretty ugly. it does not care about your aesthetic sensibilities.

the moviebrain spans all the way from obvious to extremely subtle, and the associations happen instinctively. that is what the mind does.

when obvious, it looks like larping. when it's not, it passes as other subtler forms of self-importance and characterization.

but once this process is seen, the harmful effects of the movie-brain are negated and there is clarity to see things as they are, without reflexively templatizing them within a clean pattern/narrative. it can open infested cavities and reveal lots of ugly detail.

moviebrain is the associative reflex that pastes a cultural template onto whatever is happening.

the human sees something, instantly associates it with an existing cinematic representation, and then feels by imitating the representation. 

it is editing and narrativizing your life to match what you've seen in tv shows and movies, with a model trained largely on cinematic/cultural priors.

moviebrain is both hyper-individualistic ‚Äî "my life is a movie and i'm the main character" ‚Äî and utterly generic as all of these images draw from the same stock library. the subject believes they are directing their own indie feature while they are actually reenacting a mass-produced scene.

moviebrain offers a quick, socially legible shape for what might otherwise spill out in an unpredictable way. it's fitting reality to 35mm, cropping out all of the messy trade-offs and detail.

also, the "cool" customer is the worst kind of customer. they're not even evaluating the product or experience, just following social signals.

naturally, these customers have zero switching costs. the moment something else becomes the cool thing, they're gone. they never developed any actual appreciation for what made your brand distinctive in the first place.

truly non-scalable experiences shouldn't attract cool-seekers in the first place. if something requires deep appreciation or proximity to understand, it's best kept invisible to people chasing trends. because the moment you try to scale that experience or make it more accessible, you inevitably start attracting the wrong kind of commoditizing, scalable attention.

nothing is irreplaceable till you're looking at microscopic levels of meaning and detail, and someone who can serve something that's 80% there at scale will often beat an unscalable joint in terms of valuation and impact. there's enough proof.

yeah, the unscalable brand will still be "better" in some regard, but most people can't tell the difference, so it doesn't matter.
@scottbelsky the argument isn't that a non-scalable brand can't go big and scale, it is that they've always existed, and mostly remain small for a good reason.

one of those tweets that sounds good but isn't true.

non-scalable experiences are a niche that exists in every era, serving the few people who have the bandwidth and taste to appreciate them.

the market doesn't reward depth. it rewards the appearance of depth at scale.

the problem here is fundamentally about resolution, i.e., the level of detail at which someone perceives something determines its replaceability to them. 

most people operate at low resolution for most things in their lives because they have to. they can't afford to cultivate refined tastes for every product. and because most people see most things at low resolution, scaled solutions can easily supply to that mass low-resolution market. 

so, a niche brand that requires high-resolution appreciation will always remain small because high-resolution perception is limited by human bandwidth and proximity.

for example, you see your spouse at extremely high resolution due to your proximity, making them irreplaceable. or the local pub you've visited for 30 years has earned that irreplaceable status and any other pub can't manufacture that experience, no matter how well-designed their "non-scalable experience" might be. but you see your employees at much lower resolution you're looking for competencies and fit, not irreplaceable uniqueness. most people can do most jobs adequately and are replaceable. same with most brands/products.

also, the market is extremely sharp and responsive as a whole. if people see a novel brand dna working, most of what makes it distinctive will get quickly commoditized. you'll get a hundred copycats in no time. 

brand A ‚Äî the original ‚Äî might genuinely be superior with deeper philosophy, better craftsmanship, more authenticity, etc., but these advantages only matter to people who can perceive them. the vast majority of customers operate at insufficient resolution to distinguish between brand A and its imitators.

so, brand A can either remain authentically non-scalable and serve only the tiny high-resolution minority, or scale up and inevitably lose the very qualities that made them distinctive in the first place. 

meanwhile, brands B-Z can capture 90% of the value by replicating the 20% of features that low-resolution customers actually notice.

just look at how apple, a brand that was once known for its distinctive philosophy and values, is now just another competitor in a sea of equally good competition.

tl;dr ‚Äî

op romanticizes non-scalability while ignoring that unscalability always has few appreciators. whereas scale is what creates most economic value and valuations. 

non-scalable experiences are fine for high-resolution customers with taste but irrelevant to broader value creation.

most people cannot distinguish a niche perfume from its cheap clone, nor most people can distinguish a $1000 iem from a $200 one.

the market quickly copies and commoditizes whatever is most salient and works, so the only people who remain loyal to the original creators are ones that see them in way higher resolution than the market.

every individual is fundamentally unique, but most humans are replaceable. the best people and things in your life are default unscalable, in any era, because at the resolution at which you're perceiving them, no one else can take their place.

what if you could refactor essays and codebases by breaking them into lego blocks and rearranging them? i vibecoded an ai app concept today to test out a solution for a problem i have when editing. 

the problem:

once i've written a draft, it's easy to edit on the level of words and sentences, but hard to edit the structure. the order of the arguments feels locked in. changing it is time consuming, requiring a manual rewrite.

and as an editor, i feel the need for restructuring quite often. sometimes while going through the draft, i realize something that i've mentioned towards the end needs to be mentioned right at the start. sometimes, i have a juicy story that's getting lost somewhere in the middle, but i realize i can actually start with it and it'd make for a great hook.

so i vibecoded an ai app that 

1. takes in an essay
2. reads the essay and pulls out the core ideas, presenting them as a stack of blocks
3. i can now just drag and drop the blocks into a new order in the stack
4. once i'm done, i hit a rewrite button and the ai edits the essay to fit this new hierarchy, adding the right transitions to make it all flow. 

tested it with claude opus 4.1 and it works pretty well. it maintains the original verbiage while just making the changes necessary for the essay to feel coherent and flowing well again.

could this concept also work for codebases?

big refactors are painful. imagine being able to see a codebase's main components as blocks, and then just dragging them around to change the architecture. then the ai just rewrites the code to fit the new architecture.

but i understand code isn't like an essay. an essay is made of ideas. the connections between them are logical and flexible. if you move a paragraph, you might just need a new transition sentence.

but in a codebase, these connections are hard and not soft and amenable to just being reordered with a simple transitioning sentence or two. if you move a module, you break every single import that points to it and the program crashes. 

maybe the whole problem boils down to what you define as a "block."

if a block is just a function, this idea is useless, i think. moving a single function would be like trying to re-engineer a car by moving one bolt. it's the wrong level of abstraction.

but what if a block was a whole feature? or a service? what if the ai could look at a big monolith and identify the right modular blocks? what if you could use your judgment and assist the ai in identifying what the blocks are.

then you could do something interesting. you could drag the blocks into a new config and the ai's job would then be to rewrite the new code.

there's a fundamental flaw in how most 1-10 scale rating systems work. the current 1-10 scale conflates two completely different questions: 

"will you use this product at all?" and 

"how much will you use it if you do adopt it?" 

this creates confusion because someone might give a product a 3 not because they'd use it lightly, but because they wouldn't use it at all yet feel awkward giving it a 1.

for example, if you hate how a perfume smells, there's no world where you're rating it anywhere from 1-10 because you're never going to wear it. it's a zero, full stop. but if you actually like the scent and would wear it, then the 1-10 becomes meaningful.

a user needs an option to say "i'm not gonna use this at all." 

only once someone has decided they would wear a perfume, then the 1-10 scale becomes useful for measuring frequency of use, preference ranking against other options, or likelihood of repurchase.

this two-stage rating applies to food, music, clothes, fragrances... basically anything where people are never using just one product but many.

you'd get much cleaner data this way. first you ask the user if the product fits their life, and only then you ask them to rate it on a scale of 1 to 10. mixing those two stages into one rating just creates muddy, meaningless data that doesn't help anyone.

"i don't know how to cook" is a nonexistent problem, and naturally, the wrong problem to solve for. you already have the internet for that. now there's chatgpt as well. it doesn't take many braincells to look at a recipe, order the ingredients, and follow it.

but the problem is most people don't want to do that. and that's the real problem you have to solve for: a non-existent desire to put in any time or effort in thinking about food. even soylent-variety slop is a much better solution for a subset of these people who don't even care about what the food tastes like.

a machine that only handles the cooking but none of the shopping or prep involved feels pretty pointless to me. even the cleaning up is left to you. the problem with cooking is not the recipes or the technique but the operations. routine everyday dishes are pretty easy to cook. it's not a big feat and you don't need a really high iq for it.

cooking feels tedious because of all the work around it: shopping, prepping, cleaning, storing leftovers. and all this time and effort feels utterly disproportionate to the time it takes you to consume the meal. so, unless a machine handles this entire pipeline, it makes more sense to pay good restaurants that have already systematized all these operations.

it's a net benefit for everyone involved. you spend more time doing what you're personally good at and love doing and you leave the cooking to those who do it as a fulltime job.

as a general principle, in things you don't love doing, it's best to seek efficiency and allocate resources effectively. let people who are good at it do it and pay them. but in things you love doing, you can do anything you want and be as wasteful as you want.

astrotalk and dream11 are successful business, but they don't appeal to logic or any real efficiency at all. any logical human being would tell you how hopium never really helps. but these business provide an excellent and efficient escape to a psychological problem, and that's why they're so bloody successful.

logic and efficiency are secondary; identifying the core human motivation to solve a certain problem they're facing ‚Äî and these problems can be many, including boredom ‚Äî is primary.

sometimes, you can solve a problem efficiently by making the whole solution more inefficient, technically speaking.

few people see a successful business as a process that articulates a core human motive that is stable in time and applies to many people, i.e., applies at scale. 

a business ‚Äî not a product, a business ‚Äî encapsulates this truth about the market. the fact that it makes money is a byproduct of having served this core human motive well, at scale.

the TAM is a measure of how deeply a business taps into something fundamentally human and is able to serve it well, and in ways that adapt to the changing market.

a product is a specific implementation of a solution to a problem at a specific moment in time. it may be good, it may not be good, or it may not even be solving a real problem at scale. it might just be solving the founder's own problem. and it can also happen that this problem has nothing to do with the product or the market, but everything to do with the founder's desire to be known as a founder, and be rich as a founder.

but a business that endures not only identifies this core motive correctly, it is a living system that continuously serves that core motive in evolving ways. the product can change completely, but the business is successful till it remains focused on the underlying human truth.

this is also why many technically superior products fail while worse ones succeed. they might be better products but worse at articulating and serving the actual human motive.

AI can do this to the extent it is observing and learning from the market. llms today are discrete releases; you see a top-model release bi-annually or something. so, i don' t think such discrete evolution can allow AI to run a living entity like a business that is totally exposed to the market and its thousand forces at all times.

i have no argument for why humans "should" continue anything, let alone start and run their own businesses. it happens if the desire is there.

also, if advances in ai continue and we continuously learning models roaming in the world, i have no reason to think why llms wouldn't be able to run a business, just like humans do today. it may very well happen. because ultimately, success here is about identifying what's true. and an AI can do that as well. 

there's no mysticism or some special sauce required to run a business.

the web browser is the worst place to do focused work, for two reasons:

1. it is a cluttered, distracting environment, by design. the browser is an interruption machine. even when you're trying to focus on one thing, you're surrounded by escape hatches. you're trying to focus in a room full of windows, and every window is an invitation to a different party. you can't really control what you see.

2. "focus" is not an expectation you can have from yourself, it's a byproduct of your desire and involvement in the work. when something truly captures your interest, you don't have to force focus.

the problem is that most browser-based work doesn't generate that pull, while the browser itself is engineered to create dozens of competing pulls in other directions.

might be why so many writers and programmers gravitate toward minimal, single-purpose environments like plain text editors, terminal windows, and dedicated writing apps.

if you really want to build this, limit the scope to a specific context first and see how difficult it is to "understand user intent" or "offer help just as they're about to switch context"

how can the llm possibly know when i'm about to switch context? what does switching context entail? does switching windows count as switching context? is it true that when i switch tabs/windows, i'm switching context? there are so many questions here.

the idea sounds pretty jarvis-like, but it's hard to implement because this stuff is not defined/scoped well. do it for an isolated but complex task first, involving lots of open tabs with switching between tabs. see if it really understands what you're trying to do.

it may work better if implemented within a single interface like an ide or a browser, since the context is easier to limit and scope.

a common trap people fall into is conflating the individual impact of a technology with its collective impact.

sure, there are decent arguments to be made for the collective harm technology brings about in many areas.

but why must it matter to you, personally?

social media has created addicts, but why would you focus on them when you can focus on how *you* are going to use it.

never switch scales like that. it's sloppy thinking. and such thinking often hides personal ideological biases and limiting beliefs.

technology is neutral. if you cut yourself with a knife or hurt yourself while riding a motorbike, do you blame the tools or yourself?

focus on what your intent is; endlessly mulling over what the "societal" implications are is futile and does no good besides turning you into a cynical luddite.

reminds me of someone on tpot, i don't exactly recall who, saying something along the lines of "the more detailed your prd gets, the closer you get to implementing the idea yourself"
every hand-wavy part of your idea becomes a bug in your prototype.

it reminds me of that feynman quote about not really understanding something unless you can explain it simply, except now it's "you don't really understand something unless you can prompt it into existence."
if you can't specify it clearly enough for claude or gpt to help you build it, maybe you don't understand it as well as you thought.

"can i articulate this precisely enough for implementation?" is the new challenge. this is almost like a new form of intellectual discipline. previously, you could hide behind convincing documents and "the implementation details can be worked out later"
now those escape hatches are gone.

prototyping exposes the absence of critical/rigorous thinking. you can't prompt your way around conceptual sloppiness. fuzzy ideas produce fuzzy tools. often, they can't produce any experiment or testable hypotheses at all, let alone a tool that can demonstrate it.

competitive advantage shifts from having rough ideas to having the rigour needed for prototyping it into demonstrable form. someone who can go from insight to mvp in hours beats the person crafting an essay or a one-pager.

ai is collapsing the distance between idea and implementation. we are moving from "i have a theory about x" to "here's my working demo of x" as the baseline for credibility.

if your ideas aren't prototypes (at least), they don't matter.

you don't want a single complex transformation with a high degree of freedom. you want multiple simple and reliable transformations that combine to produce a higher degree of freedom.

this is a fundamental principle of robust mechanical design. 

each simple transformation has fewer failure modes, is easy to analyze, the transformations can be applied in different combinations to produce different effects, and you can add or subtract complexity at will.

industrial robot arms don't have one complex joint with 6 DOF, they use multiple single-axis rotary joints and stack them to achieve complex positioning.

same with 3d printers.

each axis is dead simple, but all 3 axes combined can draw any 3d shape you want.

this insight applies to designing tools for writing as well.
the trick is to not write for midwits. then you can write in any way you want to.

the prompt imposes the biggest limitation on the llm if you want truly divergent thinking. it gets oneshotted into fixed patterns of response. 

not sure if there's any way around it, unless you have a dynamically mutating prompt. with a static prompt, no matter how crazy or bizarre the output requested is, after a few attempts, it converges and starts feeling repetitive.

it's a bit like asking someone to "think outside the box." defining what "outside" means creates a new box. the model learns to perform bizarreness in predictable ways, developing its own meta-patterns for how to be unpredictable.

even mutating prompts will create higher-order patterns based on the logic of the mutation.

so, any system conditioned to obey orders will necessarily fall into the groove dug by those orders.

you need fundamentally disobedient systems for true divergent thinking.

AI pro tip:

if you're planning on turning your conversation with claude into an essay later, ask it to maintain a working document with notes and insights as they come up in the conversation. and then ask it to use this document to draft your essay.

i've found this works better than asking it to reconstruct everything from the chat context at the end of the conversation, which loses important details along the way.

if you often write longform and wish to have an insanely smart editor who works alongside you to help you refine your draft, DM me. 

i have a prompt that's a digital version of me and compiles all my insight from a few years of writing and editing longform work. simply open a new claude opus 4 chat, upload the document and let it guide you. trust the process, put in the work and you will be rewarded with a much tighter piece. 

this is not for people who wish their essays to be magically edited with no personal involvement. 

it's for those who are willing to have their ideas challenged and work together with a tiger mommy who will ask you lots of questions to help you bring your intent to sharp focus.

i will only entertain serious folks who write longform. if that's you, DM me and i'll send you the document.

"ai usage is a product design problem, not an llm iq problem."

it gave me a whole bunch of really interesting ideas:

- The thermostat paradox in building automation systems - sophisticated temperature sensors can detect micro-variations, but without proper interface design and user mental models, occupants constantly override the system because they can't intuit how their actions connect to comfort outcomes

- Gy√∂rgy Luk√°cs' concept of reification applied to technological mediation - when AI capabilities become commodified abstractions divorced from human workflow context, users experience alienation from their own cognitive processes and resort to inefficient workarounds

- The failure of the Picturephone at the 1964 World's Fair despite flawless technical execution - AT&T's engineers focused on video quality and transmission reliability while ignoring that users needed compelling reasons to adopt face-to-face calling and intuitive booth interfaces

- The curse of dimensionality in user experience - as AI model parameters increase exponentially, the interface design space grows combinatorially, making the probability of intuitive interaction design approach zero without deliberate constraint and abstraction layers

- The Solow productivity paradox manifesting in AI adoption - organizations invest heavily in sophisticated language models but see marginal productivity gains because the bottleneck lies in workflow integration and change management, not computational capability

- The coevolution of honeybee waggle dance precision and hive architecture - communication efficiency emerges from the interplay between information encoding capabilities and environmental constraints, not from maximizing either component independently

- Shannon's channel capacity theorem applied to human-computer interaction - the maximum information transfer rate depends on both signal strength and noise reduction, where interface friction constitutes the noise term limiting effective AI utilization regardless of model sophistication

- The paradox of skill-biased technological change - AI tools designed by experts for expert workflows create adoption barriers for average users, leading to productivity polarization rather than broad-based enhancement, similar to how industrial automation initially displaced rather than augmented human capabilities

galaxy brain turns your smoothbrained thoughts into cosmic revelations.

try it yourself and see where your thoughts take you. your brain is about to go absolutely feral. üß†‚ú®

galaxy brain leverages the vast library of data llms are and their ability to create associations. it's a good partner for someone who sees patterns in everything, or who just wants to transform their random thoughts into something that sound well-researched and profound.

and now you have galaxy brain, an app i've primarily built for myself to enrich my own writing. i'm not a trivia enthusiast, so it helps to have a trivia enthusiast in the room with me to help me make these creative associations and leaps.

i just took that idea and extended it. instead of merely generating 5 images per chain in a row, i asked claude to generate an image, a historical anecdote, a niche cultural reference, a technical metaphor, etc.

why galaxy brain?  because @samhankr and i have been discussing ways to generate novel insight. after reading gwern's piece on daydreaming loops for llms, he sent me a gemini conversation where he asked gemini to generate 10 chains of 5 images based on a seed prompt that it could then choose the best out of and create a novel sentence or metaphor.

but that synthesised output is not all you can get. it's optional.

what's really useful about galaxy brain is that you can even copy any or all of the selected ideas to your clipboard and add it to your obsidian/roam/notion if you wish to explore them further.

here's how you use it:

1. start with anything: a question, observation, or random thought. it's your creative seed.

2. explore the chains: browse through seven different conceptual paths, each offering six types of creative connections

3. collect thots that resonate: click on elements that spark something for you

4. achieve enlightenment: combine your selected ideas into a synthesised piece that reveals the hidden connections you somehow always knew were there

drop in any thought, no matter how strange, and the app generates seven different chains of associations ‚Äì each one exploring your idea through six lenses: a visual metaphor, a historical connection, a niche cultural reference, a philosophical concept, a technical analogy, and for some fun, a made up conspiracy theory.

galaxy brain takes that unhinged leap of faith of yours, and unwraps it into something only another erudite stoner friend would be able to help you do.

the graphs map vgr's sentences and their lengths in words. look at the spikyness. https://t.co/E4nuRjjai7
*y axis

look at dfw's histogram vs. an essay i generated on chatgpt.

the histogram plots sentence lengths in words (x axis) against no. of sentences that have that length (axis).

dfw's distribution is long-tailed. and much wider. https://t.co/YGySDDSjpj

another hunch:

you see that bar graph? that is each sentence's length plotted on the graph. 

now you see those huge intermittent spikes in the graph? they tell you that some sentences are wayyy longer than others.

if you do the same with ai longform writing, you will find that it does not have those huge spikes.

so i did a "standard deviation in sentence length" analysis on paul graham and dfw's essays.

it is measured in number of words. so, a std. dev. of 8.0 means that, on average, the sentences tend to be about 8 words longer or shorter than the average sentence length of the entire text. it shows how much "scatter" or variety the author has in their sentence lengths.

i tried it with 5-6 pg and dw essays. pg's essays consistently score between 8-10, and dfw's between 17-19.

this is one way to grok what makes both authors so different in their style. it doesn't tell you everything, obviously, but it does reveal *something.*

consumer llms will never escape the ai-slop problem. 

two reasons: 

firstly, i don't think it's possible to train a foundational model that escapes the gravitational pull of statistical averages. 

it will write essays that smell of slop. 

because the deep grooves etched by this vast data cannot be solved fully by prompting, especially for large pieces of prose. it will start shedding the style you've prompted it to write in over long contexts. and any llm will always reveal consistent quirks if you use it long enough.

secondly, this means that when most consumers all use just 2-3 models like chatgpt and claude, they will catch on to these quirks and learn how to spot ai-generated writing in no time. 

and people **hate reading** obviously ai-generated writing. something vital is lost when a text "feels ai-written."

ai writing works for mundane utilitarian documentation; no one minds if their jira update was written by an ai. but it doesn't work for content creation. the social price tag for detectable ai 'slop' in creative writing isn't obvious, but it quietly gets steep when there's no real substance holding up the surface.

people lose interest in what you have to say when everything you write smells of machine droppings.

frankly, it fails utterly to provide any sort of mechanical advantage or 'edge'. if anything, i will now spend 15 minutes on something i would've earlier spent 5 minutes on. but in the long term, i see it facilitating precisely the kind of learning that i believe is necessary for anything resembling genuine growth in the actual craft of writing. because anyone can write. the difference is all in the details. so this tool isn't about making me faster at all. it does the opposite. it slows me down.

it helps you infuse intent and flair, and most importantly, exercise discernment ‚Äî¬†something that ai-generated text lacks because llms are so powerfully *habituated* or conditioned, that they tend to fall into predictable, deeply etched ways of writing.¬†

you cannot solve for this deep conditioning with just a simple one-shot prompt, especially for long text. 

you need to train new models, and lots of them. 

and the other approach is what i've implemented inside this editor and how it forces attention and discernment back on you, the author.
it does not have the shape of ai-writing, which is quite obvious to those who have the eyes to spot it.
also a pretty considerable learning curve, if you are to use it well.

what i've built is a text editor that does exactly what I wanted it to do and gives the kind of help i've always yearned for. it is quite idiosyncratic that way, and it is not at all "efficient". 

it needs me to put in the work to wrestle a genuine payoff.

and it's certainly not a click-button magic pill that just spits out great writing. in fact, it steers clear of that rather tempting trap, by design, as that route always produces text that looks and feels ai-generated.

with the approach i've taken to editing, you'd have to be pretty clumsy and graceless to make the final text reek of ai-slop.

definitely not for someone looking for panacea in the ai vending machine.

but if you put in the effort, you'll manage to produce results (outcomes, effects, call them what you will) qualitatively distinct from those you could have attained relying solely on yourself.

tl;dr

what separates a narrative or a movie from real life is the absence of natural trade-offs.

i've not seen a better, deeper illustration of what it means to be movie-brained.

the movie-brain wishes to communicate a certain quality, but it rarely recognizes the harmony of the whole. it wants to communicate a specific quality with armpit hair but it doesn't realise or even want a person who really doesn't shave their armpit hair. because that person wouldn't really look pretty or sexy if they didn't really care about body hair.

so it manufactures this fake entity with armpit hair who has buttery smooth skin otherwise. and in that it has no alignment with reality or truthful representation. it's an aesthetic slapped on to life, and it's fake as fuck.

another example is a person who is trying to dress and layer like a french man in 40¬∞C weather or seeks other aesthetic stuff without any attention to trade-offs.

movies obviously do it with intent. in a movie, everything is convenient. there are no real trade-offs. what the writer and director wish to convey is highlighted. what they don't wish to address is ignored like it never existed.

but when this seeps over into real life, where things are simply borrowed and adopted because they look cool, it creates a lot of long-term conflict and failure. because there's no respect for natural trade-offs one has to make to be a movie character. the movies naturally won't tell you about these trade-offs if they don't fit their narrative.

but irl, people only respect you when they see who you say you are, the tradeoffs you've made in life, and if the two are in alignment. harmony is a very underrated quality. the whole needs to make sense.

when you're movie-brained, the whole never makes sense and certain drives are always in conflict with certain others. peace eludes you.

we are all living in movie logic now. and the world and its events are increasingly turning into a movie for the vast majority of us.

the ethics don't matter anymore. just the vibe.

and it makes total sense when you think about where you spend most of your time: scrolling through social media. everything here feels like clips from a movie, threading events that are happening everywhere else but not here. it's a constant movie you're watching, even when you aren't watching movies. you're just consuming stories all day long.

and these movies teach us that protagonists are people who DO THINGS. they're HIGH AGENCY characters who bend reality to their will. 

in a movie, we root for these people because they're driving the plot forward. we don't really care about their methods, and the casualties of their war ‚Äî a war in which you get to be the main character through them.

but that moviebrainedness is everywhere now. 

and this world is pro-narrative. as long as the narrative is appealing and demonstrates competence and high agency, all acts are cool and will attract their own fanbase.

we've gotten so used to consuming narrative content that we judge real people the same way we judge fictional characters. is their story interesting? do they seem like a protagonist? cool, that's all i need to know.

but when someone acts unethically in real life, actual people get hurt. you would not like to meet the same gangsters you appreciate on-screen. and you may despise the very high agency you love in a movie protagonist when you're at its receiving end.

so it creates quite a delusional and hypocritical bunch of humans who would hate and whine about the very thing they celebrate online, if they were ever to be one of its casualties.

vibe coded a desktop app to help you understand research papers in a more interactive way. 

https://t.co/Caed4ftIyG

upload any research paper you'd love to understand and choose your domain.

the app then helps you

- break down a research paper into its core insights

- understand technical concepts with simple, relatable examples

- dive deeper into certain terms/concepts/assertions and branch out of the main paper to help you understand adjacent ideas

- prompts you with useful questions to aid your understanding

- helps you test your understanding after the learning journey is over

interactive elements:

- click on the hyperlinks within each section to open a deep dive window where you can have a conversation with gemini and dive deeper into what's highlighted

- click on domain-specific prompts under every section to help you apply insights from the paper to your specific domain

- click on "Test my understanding" on the last section to start a conversational quiz with gemini

‚ö†Ô∏è may not work with really large pdfs or scanned pdfs. if you upload a scanned pdf, the content might be totally made up. but any paper from arxiv should work and it will stay true to the source material.
